content.text: "Hey WILLOW, I‚Äôm trying to optimize my Docker setup for WagmiOS, but I feel like my containers are running slower than they should. Any advice?"

Check Resource Allocation ‚Äì Run docker stats to monitor CPU and memory usage per container. If certain services are hogging resources, consider setting CPU and memory limits using --cpus and --memory.

Optimize Your Images ‚Äì If your containers feel sluggish, bloated images could be the culprit. Try using docker build --no-cache and slimming down unnecessary dependencies with multi-stage builds. Alpine-based images (node:alpine, python:alpine) are often a good starting point.

Use Volume Caching ‚Äì Frequent disk reads/writes can slow things down. Bind mounts (-v /host/path:/container/path) help, but performance improves further with named volumes when persistent data is needed.

Networking Tweaks ‚Äì Docker‚Äôs default networking can introduce overhead. If your containers communicate frequently, consider using a custom bridge network (docker network create mynetwork) for reduced latency.

Enable BuildKit ‚Äì Running DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build . enables parallel processing, drastically improving build speeds.

Review Logs & Bottlenecks ‚Äì Use docker logs -f <container> and docker inspect to detect any unexpected slowdowns or misconfigurations.

If you‚Äôd like me to analyze your setup further, share your docker-compose.yml, and I‚Äôll refine my recommendations. Your system should be running like a well-oiled machine in no time. üöÄ

Would you like me to automate some of these optimizations with a script?
